newsitem.title: JAPAN: Oracle CEO says Apple would be good NC supplier.
newsitem.headline: Oracle CEO says Apple would be good NC supplier.

text.p: Oracle Corp. Chief Executive Officer Larry Ellison said Thursday that Apple Computer Inc. would be a great supplier of network computers, or NCs.

Ellison, a major promoter of new stripped-down, low-cost network computers (NCs) that can access the Internet, made the comment amid mounting industry speculation that he would soon make a bid for Apple, with the aim of turning it into a network computer manufacturer with the Macintosh brand.
Asked whether he would personally make a bid for Apple, the software billionaire said he did not want to comment, but added, "Apple would be a great supplier of NCs."
Ellison was speaking at the Oracle OpenWorld 1997 business fair in Tokyo.
Apple on Wednesday reported a $708 million fiscal second-quarter loss, which compared with a net loss of $740 million in the year-ago quarter.

However, the ailing computer maker said strong sales of speedy, new personal computers and laptops and lower expenses would help it meet its goal of reporting a profit by its fiscal fourth quarter ending in September.
Late last month, Ellison said he had formed an independent investor group to gauge interest in taking over Apple.
Ellison said at that time that he would soon decide whether to make a bid based on the reaction from Apple investors, but he added any bid would be independent of Oracle.

The move, which was not the first time Ellison had raised the possibility of personally leading a bid for Apple, came as the Cupertino, Calif.-based computer maker was struggling to recapture a profitable role in the intensely competitive PC industry.
Ellison has said for two years that he would like to buy Apple with his own money, partly to prevent Microsoft Corp. from dominating the computer industry.

Apple, with its huge following of Macintosh fans, could be a key weapon. Apple has suffered declining market share for its famous brand of easy-to-use computers and endured several rounds of restructuring in recent years.

Redwood City, Calif.-based Oracle was the top vendor in the global database market in 1996 with a 30 percent market share, according to a recent study by Dataquest, a market research firm. Dataquest said Oracle posted 1996 database revenues of $1.70 billion.
